documentType: Bureau of Prisons psychology services records
summary: This document contains a series of Bureau of Prisons psychology service records for inmate Jeffrey Epstein from July 29 to August 8, 2019, at the Metropolitan Correctional Center, New York (MCC-NY/NYM). The records detail clinical contacts, suicide risk assessments, and a disciplinary competency evaluation following an incident on July 23, 2019, where Epstein was found with a string around his neck. The records consistently note Epstein denies suicidal ideation, expresses future orientation, and is deemed psychologically stable and competent. This document contains multiple Bureau of Prisons clinical psychology reports from July 2019 documenting Jeffrey Epstein's mental status and conditions while on psychological observation/suicide watch at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York. The reports detail his complaints about SHU conditions, his claimed memory loss about neck injuries, and his psychological evaluations. This document contains a series of Bureau of Prisons psychology service notes and suicide risk assessments for Jeffrey Epstein from July 10-24, 2019, while he was incarcerated at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York. It details his psychological state, an incident on July 23 where he was found with a string around his neck, his subsequent placement on and removal from suicide watch, and his interactions with prison psychologists. This document contains multiple Bureau of Prisons psychological assessment forms for Jeffrey Epstein, conducted on July 9, 2019, the day after a court proceeding. It includes a suicide risk assessment, diagnostic formulation, and care level classification, all concluding he showed no acute mental health issues, no suicidality, and was classified as low risk. The assessments were prompted by precautionary measures due to his high-profile case and recent court appearance. This document contains multiple Bureau of Prisons psychological assessments for Jeffrey Epstein conducted on July 8-10, 2019, at the Metropolitan Correctional Center, New York (MCC-NY). It includes a suicide risk assessment, intake screening, and risk of sexual abusiveness evaluation, all concluding Epstein was at low risk, mentally stable, and denied suicidal ideation.

persons.name: Jeffrey Edward Epstein
persons.context: The subject of all psychological assessments. A 66-year-old male inmate charged with sex trafficking, assessed for suicide risk and sexual abusiveness risk. He is described as alert, cooperative, future-oriented, and denies any suicidal ideation.

persons.name: PhD/Chief Psychologist
persons.context: A Bureau of Prisons psychologist who conducted clinical contacts with Epstein on July 29 and August 8, 2019, providing supportive interventions and making housing decisions.

persons.name: PsyD
persons.context: A psychologist who conducted a suicide risk assessment on Epstein on July 23, 2019, after the string incident, concluding with a moderate acute suicide risk and recommending continued suicide watch.

persons.name: PsyD/DAPC
persons.context: A Bureau of Prisons psychologist (Deputy Assistant Psychology Coordinator) who saw Epstein for a follow-up appointment on July 31, 2019, after his removal from psychological observation.

persons.name: Unit Manager Proto
persons.context: Referred Epstein for a competency evaluation related to a disciplinary process for an incident report.

persons.name: SHU Lt.
persons.context: Mentioned as the staff member the psychologist would talk to regarding Epstein's cellmate assignment and who was informed Epstein needed an appropriate cellmate.

persons.name: Nurse Columbo
persons.context: Medical staff member who examined Epstein for numbness in his right arm and was notified again about his ongoing symptoms.

persons.name: Nick
persons.context: Epstein's old cellmate in SHU whom Epstein wanted to speak with to potentially learn what happened to cause marks on his neck.

persons.name: Ph.D.
persons.context: A psychologist who conducted assessments and clinical interventions with Epstein, notably on July 24, 2019, recommending his removal from suicide watch to psychological observation.

persons.name: PhD/Chief
persons.context: The chief psychologist who conducted multiple clinical contacts and administrative notes, addressing Epstein's complaints about conditions in the SHU and his psychological state.

persons.name: Operations Lt.
persons.context: Prison staff member who contacted the on-call psychologist in the early hours of July 23, 2019, to inform them Epstein was being placed on suicide watch after the string incident.

persons.name: Captain
persons.context: Prison official notified by the PsyD psychologist about Epstein's statement to staff that his cellmate tried to kill him; the Captain stated they were already aware.

persons.name: PsyD/PhD
persons.context: A psychologist who conducted the intake screening and risk of sexual abusiveness assessment for Epstein on July 8, 2019.

persons.name: Dr. [Redacted], Central Office
persons.context: A psychologist from the BOP Central Office consulted regarding inmate Epstein's risk factors on July 8, 2019.

persons.name: Epstein's brother
persons.context: Mentioned by Epstein as his only family, with whom he does not have a close relationship. Cited as a static risk factor (lack of family connections) in the suicide assessment.

persons.name: Epstein's attorney
persons.context: Referenced by Epstein, who expressed confidence in him, described him as 'competent,' and requested to meet with him.

connections.description: Clinical therapeutic relationship where the psychologist assessed Epstein's mental status and provided interventions.
Primary clinical and assessment relationship documented across multiple suicide risk evaluations and clinical contacts.
Unit manager referred Epstein for a psychological competency evaluation regarding a disciplinary incident.
Epstein's housing and cellmate assignments in the Special Housing Unit (SHU) were managed by this lieutenant.
Epstein was previously housed with Nick in SHU and wanted to speak with him to potentially learn what caused the marks on his neck.
Nurse Columbo examined Epstein for medical complaints including numbness in his right arm and neck.
Psychology provider who conducted regular clinical evaluations of Epstein while he was on psychological observation.
Chief psychologist who evaluated Epstein's mental status and documented his complaints about prison conditions.
Clinical relationship where the psychologist assessed Epstein's suicide risk and provided supportive interventions.
Clinical relationship where the chief psychologist addressed Epstein's complaints and conducted follow-up sessions.
Epstein described his cellmate as 'agitated' and claimed the cellmate called him a 'pedophile' and was reading a newspaper article about him.
The psychologist conducted a clinical interview and suicide risk assessment of inmate Epstein, resulting in a diagnosis of 'No Diagnosis' and a low-risk classification.
Epstein identified his brother as his only family but stated they do not have a close relationship.
Epstein expressed confidence in his attorney, described him as competent, and requested a meeting with him.
The psychologist conducted a clinical interview and suicide risk assessment of inmate Epstein.
The psychologist conducted an intake screening and risk of sexual abusiveness assessment for inmate Epstein.

events.title: Neck Injury Incident in SHU
events.description: Epstein was found in his SHU cell with a string loosely tied around his neck. An incident report (3282555) was filed charging him with code 228 (Tattooing or Self-Mutilation). The origin of the injury remains unclear.

events.title: Disciplinary Competency Evaluation
events.description: Epstein was evaluated by a psychologist for competency to proceed with the disciplinary process related to the July 23 incident. He was found competent.

events.title: Suicide Risk Assessment Triggered by Marshals
events.description: After returning from court, US Marshals had Epstein sign a form noting 'suicidal tendencies,' prompting another suicide risk assessment. Epstein denied being suicidal and seemed surprised by the form.

events.title: Psychological Observation and Discontinuation
events.description: Epstein was on psychological observation in a hospital area. Observation was discontinued on July 30, and he was returned to the SHU.

events.title: Epstein placed on suicide watch
events.description: Epstein was placed on suicide watch at 01:40 after an incident involving marks on his neck.

events.title: Epstein removed from suicide watch
events.description: Epstein was removed from suicide watch at 08:45 after 31 hours and 5 minutes on watch, following psychological evaluation.

events.title: Daily psychological observations
events.description: Epstein remained on psychological observation with daily evaluations by psychology staff, documenting his complaints and mental status.

events.title: Epstein reports memory loss about neck injury
events.description: Epstein continued to claim he could not remember how he received marks and scabbing around his neck, asking to speak with former cellmate Nick.

events.title: Epstein Found with String Around Neck
events.description: Epstein was found in his SHU cell with a string loosely tied around his neck in the early morning hours. The origin (self-inflicted or by cellmate) was unclear. This led to his placement on suicide watch.

events.title: Suicide Risk Assessment (Moderate Risk)
events.description: Psychologist (PsyD) conducted a suicide risk assessment, noting Epstein denied memory of the event, had a mark on his neck, and had told staff his cellmate tried to kill him. Concluded with a moderate acute suicide risk.

events.title: Removal from Suicide Watch
events.description: Psychologist (Ph.D.) assessed Epstein, who stated he had 'no interest in killing himself' and had 'lots to do for his legal case.' He was stepped down from Suicide Watch to Psychological Observation with a low acute suicide risk.

events.title: Epstein Placed in SHU
events.description: Epstein was placed in the Special Housing Unit (SHU) under administrative detention status.

events.title: Series of Psychological Contacts
events.description: Multiple clinical contacts where Epstein raised complaints about prison conditions (lack of spoon, soap, phone calls, cold cell, orange jumpsuit) and consistently denied suicidal ideation.

events.title: Epstein's Court Proceeding
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein attended a court proceeding, after which he returned to the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in the evening. The proceeding was noted as potentially giving him 'bad news regarding his legal situation,' prompting staff to place him on precautionary psychological observation.

events.title: Psychological Suicide Risk Assessment
events.description: Epstein was interviewed at 7:30 a.m. for a formal suicide risk assessment. The assessment concluded he had a low acute suicide risk and an absent chronic suicide risk, with no need for a suicide watch.

events.title: Diagnostic and Care Level Formulation
events.description: Epstein was classified as a CC1-MH/CARE1-MH inmate, indicating no identifiable mental illness, no significant functional impairment, and no need for regular mental health intervention.

events.title: Placement on Precautionary Observation
events.description: Epstein was placed on psychological observation status upon returning from court due to identified risk factors for suicidality, as a precaution.

events.title: Suicide Risk Assessment
events.description: A formal suicide risk assessment was conducted with Epstein. He was found to have low acute risk and absent chronic risk, with numerous protective factors outweighing risk factors.

events.title: Intake Screening and Risk Assessments
events.description: Epstein underwent BOP psychology intake screening, risk of sexual abusiveness assessment, and was informed of PREA policies upon arrival at MCC-NY.

events.title: Upcoming Bail Hearing
events.description: Epstein reported to the psychologist that he was going to have a bail hearing on the upcoming Monday and believed he would be released.

locations: Psychological observation area/hospital area at NYM
Metropolitan Correctional Center, New York (MCC NYM or NYM)
Metropolitan Correctional Center, New York (MCC-NY) - Facility: NYM
Palm Beach County jail - Where Epstein reported serving time previously
New York - Where Epstein stated he was living prior to incarceration
keyFacts: On July 23, 2019, Jeffrey Epstein was found in his SHU cell with a string loosely tied around his neck; it remains unclear if he placed it there or someone else did.
Epstein consistently denied any past or present suicidal ideation, intention, or plan across all psychological evaluations from July to August 2019.
A US Marshal form noting Epstein had 'suicidal tendencies' triggered a suicide risk assessment on August 1, 2019; Epstein was surprised and denied stating he was suicidal.
Epstein was found psychologically stable, future-oriented, and competent to proceed with disciplinary hearings related to the July 23 incident.
Epstein reported spending his days and evenings with his attorneys in the conference room and cited his lawyers and friends as emotional support.
Epstein claimed he could not remember how he received marks and scabbing around his neck that led to his placement on suicide watch on July 23, 2019.
Epstein expressed fear about returning to SHU, citing previous neck injuries there, noise preventing sleep, and concerns about safety with his former cellmate.
Psychological staff noted Epstein's vague self-report about the neck injury incident but documented his adamant denial of current suicidal ideation and future orientation.
Epstein spent most days in attorney conferences and complained about insufficient bathroom breaks during legal visits and poor conditions in SHU.
Risk factors identified included high-profile crime status, sex offender status, lack of family connections, current physical pain, and fear for own safety.
On July 23, 2019, Jeffrey Epstein was found in his SHU cell with a string loosely tied around his neck. He claimed to have no memory of the event.

Epstein told prison staff that his cellmate had tried to kill him, though he later told a psychologist he did not recall the incident and speculated his cellmate might have put the string there 'as a joke.'
Epstein's cellmate reportedly called him a 'pedophile' and was reading a newspaper article about him, which Epstein found disturbing.
Despite the incident, Epstein consistently denied suicidal ideation in multiple assessments, stating he had 'no interest in killing himself' and had 'lots to do for his legal case.'
Prison psychologists assessed his acute suicide risk as 'Moderate' on July 23 but 'Low' on July 24, leading to his removal from Suicide Watch to Psychological Observation.
On July 9, 2019, a Bureau of Prisons psychologist assessed Jeffrey Epstein as having no mental health diagnosis, no history of mental health treatment, and no current suicidality.
Epstein was placed on precautionary psychological observation on July 8, 2019, after returning from a court proceeding that might have contained bad legal news.
The suicide risk assessment concluded Epstein's overall acute suicide risk was 'Low' and chronic risk was 'Absent'; a suicide watch was not warranted.
Epstein was classified as a CARE1-MH inmate, meaning he showed no significant mental illness and required no regular mental health intervention.
Epstein reported past incarceration in Palm Beach County jail on sex offense charges (soliciting prostitution) and was currently facing federal sex trafficking charges.
On July 9-10, 2019, BOP psychologists assessed Jeffrey Epstein as having a 'Low' acute suicide risk and 'Absent' chronic suicide risk, determining a suicide watch was not warranted.
Epstein explicitly and repeatedly denied any past or present suicidal ideation, intent, or plan during multiple clinical interviews, stating he was future-oriented and committed to life.
Epstein was assessed as being at 'Low Risk of [Sexual] Abusiveness' at the facility, though he had a history of prior sexual abuse perpetration in the community.
The assessments note Epstein had just come from a court proceeding on July 8, 2019, which 'may have given him bad news,' triggering the precautionary psychological evaluation.
Epstein reported to psychologists that he had an upcoming bail hearing and believed he would be released from jail.
